replyContent:
The app will run in the background, to minimize battery consumption, without affecting your phone’s operation. All you need is to keep your Bluetooth on whenever you leave your house.

Battery life may be quite different between models. If you are experiencing issues with your battery, please turn off Bluetooth when you are home.

How close they have been to another user diagnosed with COVID-19.
How long they’ve been near that person, cumulatively, over a period of time.
How many days since that contact occurred (anytime over the last 14 days).

content: It only tracks exposures longer than 15 minutes. The only people I am with that long would tell me if they were exposed.
replyContent: Hi Geoff - The app defines an exposure as less than two meters between yourself and someone for more than 15 mins, based on public health guidance. As one of many tools we have to combat COVID-19, the app doesn't replace manual contact tracing, physical distancing or wearing a mask, but it can help reduce transmission at all levels of uptake.

content: It is an okay app, but needs improvement. You shouldn't have to be around someone with Covid for 15 minutes or longer before the app detects a Covid positive person. replyContent: Thanks for your feedback, Chris. The app will notify you if you have been within two metres for more than 15 minutes (or "close contact", based on public health guidance) with someone who then tested positive for COVID.

content: Part 1: I had to fight to connect with real developers. No real tech support at that time. They seem to have broadened the phones it works on. But the underlying concept of privacy during a pandemic is completely misguided. Also - sick or worried people should NOT be expected to report positive results; only 5% remember to do so. App also assumes that we all have data plans and Bluetooth always on. Part 2: They've responded, and say we need to go online with the PHONE every day. They lack a grasp of the basic fact that not everyone has a data plan - so those who don't are being told to go to a wifi zone (maybe indoors) every day - even though in a pandemic we should be staying OUT of public places as much as possible. I really wanted to participate in this app, but when only 5% of those who have it actually use it properly, it is almost a total technology and public health failure. I see the lost potential of masks (a simple partial solution) and an app (a complex partial solution) being a combined failure of public health.
replyContent: Thanks for your feedback, Ivan. COVID Alert is one part of our public health effort to limit COVID-19, and the app doesn’t replace manual contact tracing by public health authorities or wearing a mask and physical distancing. At all levels of uptake, the app is one tool that can help reduce transmission and death.
